summary: This document is a series of email exchanges from March to June 2019, primarily from an Assistant U.S. Attorney in the Southern District of New York, requesting travel approval for victim interviews and meetings in Los Angeles and Florida related to the investigation 'United States v. Epstein, 2018R01618'. The emails detail logistical planning for trips to conduct interviews in the ongoing Epstein sex trafficking investigation.

connections.description: Both are part of the investigative team traveling to conduct victim interviews for the Epstein case.
Both are part of the investigative team traveling for meetings and interviews in Florida for the Epstein case.

events.title: Initial Florida Travel Request
events.description: Assistant U.S. Attorney S requests travel approval for a 2-day trip to West Palm Beach and/or Fort Lauderdale, Florida, for meetings and interviews related to the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Florida Travel Approval
events.description: Travel request for a 3-day trip to West Palm Beach, Florida, for meetings and interviews related to 'United States v. Epstein, 2018R01618' is approved.

events.title: Follow-up Florida Travel Request
events.description: S requests travel approval for approximately three days to West Palm Beach, Florida, for victim interviews, noting difficulty pinning down timing with victims.

events.title: Los Angeles Travel Request
events.description: S requests travel approval for a trip to Los Angeles next week for a victim interview, planning to fly Wednesday and return by Friday.

keyFacts: The document references the ongoing federal investigation 'United States v. Epstein, 2018R01618', described as 'an investigation relating to enticement of minors for sexual activity'.
Prosecutors from the Southern District of New York were actively conducting victim interviews in multiple locations (Los Angeles and Florida) in mid-2019, indicating a broad investigative scope.
The emails show a pattern of requesting permission to reserve hotel conference rooms for conducting victim interviews, suggesting a formal, secure interview process.
The travel requests span from March to June 2019, showing sustained investigative activity in the months leading up to Epstein's arrest in July 2019.
The correspondence indicates logistical coordination challenges, specifically in 'pinning down timing for interviewing the victims'.
